pullRequest.body:
This is the next PR in a sequence that establishes general results on L-series.
See [this thread on Zulip](https://leanprover.zulipchat.com/#narrow/stream/144837-PR-reviews/topic/L-series/near/424858837).

This adds the definition of the Dirichlet convolution of two sequences (as `LSeries.convolution`) and shows that the associated L-series is the product of the L-series associated to the two original sequences.

---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]
-->

[![Open in Gitpod](https://gitpod.io/button/open-in-gitpod.svg)](https://gitpod.io/from-referrer/)

nodes.body:
LGTM

maintainer merge
🚀 Pull request has been placed on the maintainer queue by loefflerd.

Pull request successfully merged into master.

Build succeeded:
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/8426452589/job/23074786544)
  * [Check all files imported](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/8426452589/job/23074785515)
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/8426452589/job/23074785841)

Thanks :tada:

bors merge

Thanks :tada:

bors merge
maybe `LSeries_convolution_eq_mul` is a better name?

This is in line with `LSeries_add` (the L-series of a sum) and `LSeries_sub` (the L-series of a difference). But of course, here the opration on the right is not the same as on the left.
I have no strong feelings here, but would perhaps like further input.
If you prefer this name that's fine
The name doesn't seem right; perhaps `ArithmeticFunction.coe_mul`, or even `ArithmeticFunction.coe_mul_eq_convolution`? I would also rather spell the conclusion as `f ⍟ g = ↑(f * g)`.
OK. I take `ArithmeticFunction.coe_mul`; the alternative does not fit so well as the equality is written the other way round.

I was confused by this – the formulation seemed bizarre ("why is he taking a `tsum` over an obviously finite set?") until I realised that the index set on the RHS is infinite if `n = 0` (in particular, it doesn't match `Nat.divisorsAntidiagonal n`). Maybe a clarifying comment might be a good idea? I also think it might be a good idea to also provide the formulation in terms of `Nat.divisorsAntidiagonal` first, as a separate lemma, and then deduce this formulation from that (the total length of those two proofs would be comparable to this single big one).
OK. I'm splitting off the `Nat.divisorsAntidiagonal` version. I have also added some text to the docstrings and golfed the proof a little bit.

How about
````
let m : ℕ × ℕ → ℕ := fun p ↦ p.1 * p.2
  rcases eq_or_ne n 0 with rfl | hn
  · -- show that both sides vanish when `n = 0`
    refine (term_zero ..).trans ?_ 
    -- the right hand sum is over the union below, but in each term, one factor is always zero
    have hS : m ⁻¹' {0} = {0} ×ˢ univ ∪ univ ×ˢ {0} := by
      ext
      simp only [mem_preimage, mem_singleton_iff, _root_.mul_eq_zero, mem_union, mem_prod, mem_univ,
        and_true, true_and, m]
    convert tsum_zero.symm using 3 with ⟨⟨a, b⟩, hab⟩
    simp only [hS] at hab
    rcases hab with ⟨rfl, -⟩ | ⟨-, rfl⟩ <;> simp only [term_zero, zero_mul, mul_zero]
  · -- now `n > 0`
    have H : m ⁻¹' {n} = n.divisorsAntidiagonal := by
      ext
      simp [m, hn]
    rw [H, Finset.tsum_subtype' n.divisorsAntidiagonal fun x ↦ term f s x.1 * term g s x.2]
    exact term_convolution' ..
````
(sorry, github won't let me make this as a "suggestion")
(If you select the range of lines (so that they are highlighted) before clicking on the "Comment" button, and then click on the `±` symbol, the suggestions stuff should work.)
(I'm aware of the interface, but github doesn't support making suggestions on line ranges that include one or more deleted lines.)
The `convert` is fairly slow, so I do the vanishing of the terms first, but the re-arrangement looks good!
(OK; I hadn't noticed that before.)
I feel the primed and non-primed versions should be the other way around.
OK.
You marked this as "resolved" but the naming didn't change – did you perhaps swap a different primed/unprimed lemma pair instead?

I thought you meant `LSeries_convolution` and its primed variant; I guess I didn't read carefully.
Regarding `term_convolution`, the (currently) unprimed version is the one that is actually used, that's why I left it unprimed. If you think the other one is more useful outside, I can also change it there.
Should I revert the other changes? One version is in terms of `LSerieSummable`, the other in terms of abscissae of convergence, and I don't know whether there is a reason to consider one more canonical than the other...

I feel the version with `sum` and `divisors_antidiagonal` is a more natural statement, hence my suggestion. But let's not spend too long debating over a single character! :-) I have no strong opinion about the other one.
I've switched them now; I'm leaving the other ones.

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat(NumberTheory/LSeries/Convolution): new file; convolution of sequences and products of L-series
